The Suffocation of the Sacred in our Age

16/11/2022

Sophia Ash (she/her) discusses the importance of individuality within sacred spaces

Image by Image Credit: TRUTHSEEKER08

By Katy Leverett

To think of what is sacred immediately conjures up ideas of religion. We think of the devotional care of religious sacrament, of rituals performed with unwavering dedication and constancy. In our age of swelling secularisation and disenchantment, spiritual values have been slowly eclipsed by the assailment of things giving us quick gratification, engendering a wane in the value of the ritual and the sacred. While this decline in tradition, particularly religious, has enabled the birth of new, arguably freer, ways of thinking of and engaging with the world, it has also cultivated a way of being that is out of touch with what is most present, immediately tangible and, perhaps, most important. We are constantly bombarded by news, products and trends so that weâ€™re always poised for the next thing, the next craze, intoxicated by newness and whatever is fashionable. Pausing for breath, appreciating what is utterly still, sacred, and perpetuating, is increasingly rare. The pace of time and experience has accelerated, and dangerously so.

It is important to disentangle what we mean by sacred, outside of religious associations. Consider connection, moments, experiences; what is rooted in the present as opposed to a sacred value or worth imposed on objects or enactments by doctrine or tradition. Thinking of the sacred in freer terms, more centred on what is immediately present and tangible to us, multiplies what has the potential to be thought of as sacredâ€“ an idea that I believe to be immeasurably more significant than we are aware of, one that is often taken for granted. To assign a sense of sacrality onto what is mundane infuses life with the value, beauty, and importance that so easily falls by the wayside, forgotten. If we limit ideas of the sacred solely to ideas of religion, the emergence of secularism on both a social and individual level excludes what can be thought of as sacred. The growth and prevailing influence of capitalism and consumer culture, as well as the sway of secularism, has rapidly and tragically suffocated ideas of the sacred.

As an inevitable symptom of living in this fast paced cultural climate, the ways in which we experience time have been distorted, which then imposes on our engagement with the spaces we inhabit. This is important in scrutinising how our temporal and spatial experiences of the sacred have shifted with these cultural transformations. If we trace back to times pre-capital, before the industrial revolution, when the economy was centred around agriculture, time had an altogether different meaning, a different imposition on the human experience. It would have, inmost cases, been recognised as something cyclical, echoing the motions of seasons and harvests for agricultural purposes. To live in rhythm with the cycles of the rains, the dry seasons, the spring, the winter, was essential to survival, to mark the ripening of crops, and so the sustenance of the individual and the community.

This is all assuming that these places are seasonal as opposed to perennial. Both the industrial revolution and the inflating prevalence of Christianity has cultivated a linear perception of time, moving away from aligning temporality with harvests and seasons. If we return to our current age and our experience of time now, our linear conception of it has, I would argue, not only been amplified, but become something increasingly harmful; it is an exponential line of endless growth and progress. For todayâ€™s social climate is one infatuated by notions of perpetual progression, ambition, development, and ours is an emotional climate also predicated on feelings concerning the future... desires, anxieties... all of which have contributed to the escalating crisis of mental illness among us. Would these kinds of emotionsâ€“ that is, anxieties concerning the futureâ€“ have such a deeply rooted place in a cyclically conceived-of time frame? And how have these conceptions of linear time imposed upon and distorted our experienceâ€“ or even, our ability to experienceâ€“ the sacred?

If we examine how we engage with time in our age, the almost obsessive tendency towards routine is glaringly obvious. Linking this back into notions of the sacred, a slight semantic alteration can change our ideas of these formulaic living structures to convey something closer to that sacredness in jeopardy of being forgotten entirely. Modern day rituals, less embedded in religious meaning, can be better understood as this tendency towards routine. And so â€˜routineâ€™ becomes â€˜sacred ritual,â€™ though situated in our current context. But routine doesnâ€™t evoke the same kind of value suggested by the term â€˜ritual.â€™ Rather, it is a schedule, a sequence of actions regularly followed and though â€˜ritualâ€™ is similarly composed of a series of actions prescribing to some kind of order, there is necessarily an emotional or spiritual weight attached to it that elevates it to metaphysical dimensions. To attach to â€˜routineâ€™ some kind of emotional depth, would endanger it inits propensity to teeter into the realm of neurosis and OCD, where it becomes a schedule that, if not abided by, triggers anxiety and feelings of being out of balance with everyday patterns.

And thus emerges a vulnerability to hyper-fixations, escalating into harmful mentalities that taint any kind of sacrality that may be found in routine (or the â€˜modern-day ritualâ€™). Again, we can trace this back to our conception of time which has, somewhat paradoxically, been heavily moulded by the grand narratives of Christianity and capitalism pervading our cultural climate. I say paradoxically, for â€˜the sacredâ€™ seemingly derives from religion, though its harmful imposition on our experience of time has diminished our openness to the very sacredness it values so highly. As for capitalism, its promotion of efficiency, accessibility and broader freedoms and opportunities, while pointing towards heightened contentment, only seems to lead us spiralling in the opposite direction.

And so, the temporal linearity through which we experience our age imposes on our experience of the sacred. Tugged along as we are in a collective drive towards future experience, routine or ritual (in any sense of the word) is distorted into becoming a mere means to an end, a leverage for some future contentment. Is this not desacralizing in its most palpable form? Sacrality necessarily concerns a rootedness in the present moment, a devotion centred on that one experience alone. The distance routine has from the sacredâ€“ on account of our capitalistic environmentsâ€“ means the term cannot be interchangeable with ritual. Not only is it the tendency to cultivate neurotic mentalities and hyper-fixations that makes routine harmful, but we must also acknowledge how routine can limit us, encourage an idle mind, a temptation to fall into the comfort of monotony, ultimately restricting our potential to grow in new, unfamiliar environments. I think of working 9-5 every day in an office; of years, and decades, of the same school routine growing up; of waking and sleeping at the same time each day; of eating and resting at the same time each day, and I struggle to see the desirability in this kind of lifestyle... It allows for too much automated living.

However, it is important to acknowledge that routine does provide a form of certainty that allows for focus. In this sense, it can overlap with ritual... It can also harness creative talent, or physical strength by repeated practice that allows for the growth of a skill. This kind of repetitive order can be seen to be important, or even as resonating with the sacred, for a period of time, but is it really possible to stretch ourselves, open ourselves to expansion and discovery in a practical, dislocating, truly meaningful sense while being caged in the routine of our cultural climate?

Our time and space, the pace of lives and the distortion of values has complicated the way we experience what is sacred, sending us sprawling and seeking some kind of foundation, though increasingly confused as to what that may be. The chronic restlessness we seem to suffer from demands a change, if not in our collective environmental engagements, then at the least in mentality. So how can we synthesise these oppositions and contradictions to recover the value of the sacred in our age?

Creating a space individual to youâ€“ an act so simple, yet so valuableâ€“ may provide a way out from this chaos of conflicting values. But it is, perhaps, more weighted an act than initially thought of. In our social climate bent on herding us into a universal ideal, desire, ambition, the creation of a sacred spaceâ€“ one that is individual, distinctiveâ€“ is an act of transgression. There is an undeniable struggle to assert individuality in our environment, but it is possible, on the most intimate and immediate level, concerning the space we inhabit in the very creation of that space as something unique only to you.To strip it down to the most accessible though personal level, something as simple as a university bedroom has the possibility to become a sacred space. It is an escape, a constant, a cocoon of warmth and security. By breathing life into a space, possessing what has no practical purpose to charge a space with meaning, littering a room with art, relics, heirlooms understood in all their emotional dimensions only to you, the sacred can overlap with the deeply personal, can rupture the norms of time and space. Like religious icons and revered books, everything you fill your space with, even if it is a single picture beside your bed, can create something immeasurablyvaluable. It is an assertion of individuality madepossible in a way that coalesces with the sacred,a pause for breath in an age swamped in idealsof quick gratification. Though delusive in itssimplicity, the creation of sacred space may justprovide the rootedness we grapple for in this ageof pervasive restlessness.
